text: now that we've had this collection of
documents from Guantanamo disclosed what
does this mean about the future of the
prison it's interesting that these
documents come to light now because it
appears that this is a sort of important
moment in the history of this prison
almost ten years old now there are now
172 people left out of about 779 who
have passed through there but it looks
increasingly like these 172 or almost
all of them are likely to be there for
the foreseeable future and that
Guantanamo will be a at least an
enduring part of the American sort of
policy landscape what are the political
reasons for that well Republicans and
some Democrats in Congress have been
adamantly opposed to bringing detainees
from the prison to the US mainland for
trials or even for long-term detention
there's been this sort of notion that
somehow these folks even if in prison
would pose some kind of threat to
Americans so Congress has essentially
tied the hands of the administration
made it very difficult for it to move
people out of there those remaining are
they the hardest of the hard core are
there a few that there's still some
expectation could leave it's a real
mixed bag these 172 their range on the
one hand from people like Khalid Sheikh
Mohammed the infamous chief plotter of
the 911 attacks to a significant number
several dozen people from Yemen who have
been cleared for release they've been
basically declared not a not a danger
but there's reluctance to send them home
to Yemen because of chaos there because
there's an active al-qaeda branch there
and other countries have not exactly
been clamoring to accept them either
President Obama famously pledged just
weeks into office that he would close
the prison in Cuba it shows how on the
one hand Congress and the courts have
made it difficult to close on the other
hand his own review he ordered a review
all these detainees a new review of who
they were and what danger they might
pose and they his own review and
up finding 47 people who they did not
believe they had evidence to try but
they feared would be too dangerous to
release so he sort of accepted the
principle that some of these people
might be incarcerated basically forever
and the uproar over trying one of the
911 plotters must have reinforced the
public discomfort with the notion
releasing some of these people even for
a trial in the United States this became
a kind of political football and the
notion of the 911 platters coming back
to New York for a trial became a symbol
and even Democrat sort of ran the other
way so it turns out that this prison
down in Cuba is a little bit out of
sight out of mind far away and from a
political standpoint it has a certain
appeal to Americans so what began as a
ad hoc experiment in detention may be
with us for quite some time it's hard to
imagine this prison closing anytime in
the next several years
